resource.string: Pestilence grips the men. Its origins are unknown but it has spread throughout the ranks. Survivors work to collect the dead, and funeral pyres burn day and night... And the sickness spreads.
The Horses from Across the Sea
The Horses from Across the Sea
The Horses from Across the Sea
The Horses from Across the Sea
The Dolphin Rider
The Dolphin Rider
The Dolphin Rider
Description of Greece
The woman was confined and died shortly. Some mutter that it was grief that killed her. Her son refused to fight for the person responsible for destroying his entire family.
Thankful for your mercy. The woman's son offered his service in place of his father, and proved to be a promising general.
Despite barbarian marauders stealing the hoard, nasty rumours speak of the Claudii having taken done it. Their influence with the people and the Senate has diminished.
Groups of angry citizens appeared at your door demanding to know who was going to pay them full value for the slaves they had lost.
The executions calmed the mind of the magistrate, but set a fire in hearts of the remaining slaves. They were outraged that men and women had been put to death on the whim of one man.
The magistrate insisted his fears were not baseless. The number of runaway slaves increased, and there were even reports of slaves attacking their masters!
The offerings were made and the people waited to see if the gods approved of these strange foreign gifts. The gods were pleased, and blessed our people with good weather and a bountiful harvest.
These new and exotic items brought traders from far and wide to our lands and trade flourished.
People travelled from miles around to purchase incense and spices. As the only local source for these exotic items the tribe's wealth soared.
The tribe's trade continued much as it had before the arrival of the trader.
Earthquake
Description of Asia
Nothing happened. It seems the gods are satisfied.
We have given thanks to the gods and all is well.
The cow was afflicted by gadfly! We have angered the Queen of the Gods!
The celebrations lasted long into the night and both gods and men were pleased. People did not rush to their work next morning…
The Bones of Monsters
The Bones of Monsters
The Bones of Monsters
The Oracle of Zeus Ammon
Tyrian Purple
Tyrian Purple
Tyrian Purple
The celebrations lasted long into the night. People with woozy heads struggled to return to their work the next morning!
The offerings were made and the people rejoiced. As the astrologers promised, the following years saw bumper harvests and your people prospered.
The astrologers predictions were correct! The years that followed the alignment were incredibly prosperous for you and your people.
After being publicly chastised she apologised, but that was not the end of it. Patrician women rallied to the woman's cause and openly mocked your family for what they saw as an act of cowardice.
Following your praise of the lady for a wanton act of violence, the Senate and the other patrician families began to think twice before crossing you and yours.
Proud of his strong and virtuous wife, her husband showered her with gifts and all the other women of the family were mad with jealousy.
Bad Omen
Bad Omen
Bad Omen
Bad Omen
Blood is Blood
Blood is Blood
Blood is Blood
Blood is Blood
Displeased with her fat old husband your daughter quickly returned to her old ways, shaming both you and her new husband.
Romans love to gossip; some other harlot will come along and distract them in no time.
The gods welcomed her with open arms and gifted her with 'the sight.' Her visions are heard and respected by all Romans.
Word of the kings' all-too-clear mortal status has reached the people. Some now openly say that he is no Alexander; others question his right to rule.
The Slaver
The Slaver
The Slaver
The Slaver
The rich new colour produced by the merchant's dye became popular with the nobles of the tribe. Before long it was a symbol of importance, fetching higher prices than any other goods.
The tribe's trade continued much as it had before the arrival of the trader.
The new colour was beautiful to behold and the people of the tribe looked in envy.
Troubling news: informants speak of a plague gripping this foreign army. Contact should be avoided.
They came in the dead of the night. The woman and her child were never seen again…
The woman took the money and returned to her homeland. True to her word, both she and her brat were never seen again.
The boy was adopted and raised by your family. As he grew it became more and more obvious that the woman had been truthful: the child was truly of your blood.
The woman withdrew from court life to raise her child. As he grew the boy favoured his father. The people were in no doubt as to his lineage.
Bandits
Bandits
Bandits
Nothing happened, as expected. We are the gods' faithful, so why would they punish us?
The gods are pleased by our noble sacrifice.
The sky darkens and lightning rips the clouds. Our meagre sacrifice has angered the mighty gods.
After being manhandled from the city the traveller cursed everyone. So? We have nothing to fear from a madman.
The boys behaviour became too much for some members of your family to stomach. He disappeared from one of his haunts of depravity and was never heard from again.

The boy continued to shame the family with his acts of debauchery. His mother doted on him and convinced herself that he was now a good boy, but the rest of the family knew better and questioned your judgement.
The boy was put to death and his mother wept for his loss. Afterwards, other young members of your family became strangely well behaved. The fate of the boy served as a lesson in poor conduct.
The boy returned to his home in exile and soon resumed his life of foul debauchery. His mother was mortified and never spoke her son's name again.
Somehow, somwhere, someone talked, and the the Julii's part in the disappearance of the gold of Tolosa is now known. Their influence with the people and the Senate is now greatly diminished.
Somehow, somwhere, someone talked, and the the Junii's part in the disappearance of the gold of Tolosa is now known. Their influence with the people and the Senate is now greatly diminished.
Volumes describing the sights and customs of Hellas have emerged. These offer much to those who dream of travel in foreign lands.
His new-minted divinity has helped the king's influence to grow. The people are inspired!
Careless Sons
Careless Sons
Careless Sons
Deadly Rumours
Deadly Rumours
Deadly Rumours

Word of the deposit spread quickly and soon the hills were swarming with people hoping to exploit the rich ore deposit. Many had no mining experience and the hastily dug and poorly maintained shafts soon collapsed, killing all those inside.

The expansion of the mines was costly but the new ore more than paid for the work. Miners claimed they had never seen anything like it and the further they dug, the more they found. This was surely a gift from the gods!
The man was killed cleanly and laid to rest with all the honour due one in his position. Within days of his death the rains finally came and the crops grew once more.

The magistrate was banished from his province. The land recovered and the people rejoiced. However, the lands where he walked soon fell victim to his taint, and their inhabitants were outraged that you had knowingly sent forth an accursed man.
The man and his taint continued to befoul the soil and the people of his province starved. Those who survived talked openly of your failure to help them.
Snow Storms
The attack on the convoy is complete. No one survived to speak of the gold of Tolosa ogoing to the Hannonid family.
Following her punishment the concubine left the court for a time. Shortly after, your wife was found dead in the gardens of your home, poisoned.

After having her plots revealed to the entire court the concubine was ostracized. There were rumours that she had attempted to recruit people to her cause, but she had lost what little influence she once had.
The woman was publically put to death. The number of plots and schemes in your court apparently decreased dramatically.
The pirates, angered by your refusal to pay, decided the boy was more trouble than he was worth. He was never seen again.

The fool boy was released and swaggered back into his family home boasting of the huge sum that had been paid to secure his release. After being properly chastised by his father he remembered his place and has brought no further trouble to the family.
The child grew and it was obvious that the astrologers had been right: bad luck followed wherever he went and people feared to be near him.

After receiving your generous gift the astrologers re-examined the signs. They found that the planets had moved shortly before the child's birth, so he had not been born under the influence of baleful stars! Amazing!
The baby and its mother were sent away and the people breathed a sigh of relief.
Curses! A band of merciless raiders has taken everything and left none alive! Could the Volcae's curse be true?
Description of Egypt
The woman was put back on a ship and returned to her masters. Your refusal to accept their generous gift was taken as an insult and relations between you suffered.
The beautiful woman remained at court for a short time but, when it became obvious that you were indifferent to her charms, she boarded a ship and returned to her homeland.
The woman was beautiful and charming. Her masters were pleased that you had accepted her as a gift, as were all the men of your court.
The Gold of Tolosa
Mad as a March Hare
Mad as a March Hare
Mad as a March Hare
Ill Omens
Ill Omens
Ill Omens
Ill Omens
The women took their punishment and all was peaceful, for a time. They soon returned to their plots and intrigues.
The concubines continued to plot and scheme but, ultimately, they had no power and their plots were of little consequence.
Following the public execution of the poisonous schemers life at court became peaceful. The plotting came to an end as all knew you were not to be crossed.
The Gift of Beauty
Blood is Blood
The Gift of Beauty
Blood is Blood
The Gift of Beauty
Blood is Blood
The Gift of Beauty
Blood is Blood
The boy trained tirelessly and studied under some of the greatest minds of the age. As he grew it became obvious that he would go on to achieve great things.
The boy became a well respected priest, and the gods were thankful to our family for sending such a fine boy to the temple.
For once the rumours were true. The boy sat a horse better than men twice his age and his swordsmanship was beautiful to behold. The family were proud to have him as one of their own.
All that Glitters...
All that Glitters...
The seas stayed becalmed for a short while, but soon good winds resumed and all returned to normal.
The winds returned in an instant and trade flourished once more. The child's mother has yet to recover, but her sacrifice was for the greater good.
Poseidon was unmoved by your sacrifice. The seas remained flat calm and our trade suffered as a result.
Fallen Vestal
Fallen Vestal
Fallen Vestal
Fallen Vestal
The two men fought and the magistrate was injured. He soon recovered from his wounds and he, and the young general, continued to serve you loyally.
On further investigation it was found that the woman had tried to seduce the young general and been spurned. Upon learning the truth, her husband cast her out and apologised all concerned.
The young man continued to profess his innocence right up until the moment of his death.
Word of the awful crime spread and the mob vowed vengeance for the murdered boy. They dragged the man from his home in the dead of night and made him pay for his crimes, repeatedly.
When his sentence was read out the man broke down and insisted that it was not right for a citizen of Rome to suffer the same fate as slaves and foreigners.

The people were outraged that you allowed a crime of this magnitude go unpunished. Some took to the streets to denounce you and others whispered in the shadows. In the end, the mob left you a grisly message and justice was done.
Crowds gathered to watch the murderer receive his just punishment. The cheer as he was hurled from the Tarpeian Rock was deafening.
The Greek Affair
The Greek Affair
The Greek Affair
The Greek Affair
There is talk of a pestillence gripping nearby lands. Beware the spread of disease.
She took the money and will never darkened our door again.
The payment was enough to see that the child and its mother were never seen again.
The hetaira took the small fortune offered her and was never seen again.
Athena is a proud goddess! She has been angered by your support of this harlot.
Word soon spread of the woman's disappearance and it didn't take long for blame to land at our door, a stain on the family name.
The woman was kidnapped and sold into slavery. News of her fate soon spread and people whispered that you were not to be crossed.
Following the trial Phryne became an outcast. No self-respecting man would pay for her services and her own kind shunned her.
The fool refuses to see the error of his ways and insists that she is the only woman for him.
The bastard is born and bares an uncanny resemblance to his father. The integrity of our house is openly mocked by all.
The woman soon attached herself to another, more powerful man, forcing the general to admit defeat.
The women were put on trial for all to see. This seemed to please Aphrodite, though their families were less pleased.
When the child was born it looked nothing like its supposed father, exposing the woman's slanderous lies.
Aphrodite was outraged by your failure to act on behalf of the hetaira. A woman given beauty by the goddess should have been protected.
The gods have more pressing concerns, this woman is of no concern to them or us.
Aphrodite was pleased with your offerings. She decided not to punish you for your failure to protect the hetaira.
A Promising Youth
A Promising Youth
A Promising Youth
Oaken Whispers
Oaken Whispers
Oaken Whispers
Oaken Whispers
A Heavy Price
A Heavy Price
A Heavy Price
No one is safe from the vengeance of the gods. The ground trembles, buildings crumble and the dead litter the ground, crushed beneath the rubble.
Incense and Spice and all Things Nice
Incense and Spice and all Things Nice
Incense and Spice and all Things Nice
Incense and Spice and all Things Nice
Slaves, Slaves, Everywhere
Slaves, Slaves, Everywhere
Slaves, Slaves, Everywhere
The Wife of the Magistrate
The Wife of the Magistrate
The Wife of the Magistrate
A Heavy Price
A Heavy Price
Tomb Robbers
The tribe's trade continued much as it had before the arrival of the trader.
The offspring of the magnificent stallions were the most impressive animals anyone had ever seen: strong, swift and beautiful.
The arrival of this trader drew others to our lands and trade flourished.

The horses were given to our finest warriors. They were in awe of the beasts. The rumour quickly spread that they were a blessed gift from the horse goddess, and the men treated them with the utmost respect.
Lost Love
A Question of Blood
Lost Love
Wrath of Athena
Lost Love
Wrath of Athena
A Question of Blood
Wrath of Athena
A Question of Blood
Wrath of Athena
Wrath of Aphrodite
A Question of Blood
Wrath of Aphrodite
Lost Love
Wrath of Aphrodite
The Price of Loyalty
The Price of Loyalty
The Price of Loyalty
Sand Storms
The Gift of Beauty
The Gift of Beauty
The Gift of Beauty

The gods demanded a slow death. The man was strangled, hit on the head, had his throat cut and was finally thrown into a bog. As his body sank below the surface a hare appeared, a sure sign that the gods had seen the sacrifice and were well satisfied with it.
Punishment was not enough for the gods. Blood was what they expected. They showed their distain for your feeble efforts by sending torrential rains that destroyed crops and homes.
The people of the tribe were never going to let such an affront to the gods go unpunished. The man's body was found, riddled with stab wounds: the blood debt had been paid.

The Egyptian quickly became the favourite of the thinkers in the family and the warriors favoured the Scythian. Both men had much to teach us and were happy to share their knowledge with their new masters.
The Scythian proved to be a wise investment. He had much to teach the family about horsemanship, and the right way to raise and train horses.
The Egyptian proved to be a wise investment. He was a great success at feasts, where he would recite poetry and plays in several languages for the amusement of the guests.
The slaver was insulted by your refusal to honour him with your patronage but their was little he could do about it.
Rumours has it that the Gold of Tolosa was not taken by bandits. It is supposedly now the property of Magonids! These foul rumours diminished our influence in the council.
Deadly Rumours
Deadly Rumours
Deadly Rumours
Jupiter's curses on our enemies! A band of raiders has plundered everything and killed everyone. Is the Volcae's curse coming to pass?
Good Omens
Good Omens
Good Omens
No one knows where the plague came from but it does not matter now. The dead are countless and it continues to spread. Those who survive live in dread, and the local economy has been devastated.
Valuable Information
Valuable Information
Valuable Information
Valuable Information
Chalcon soon tired of your lack of hospitality and moved on to find a more hospitable host.
Angered by your refusal to see him, Chalcon spread Pythia's prophesy far and wide. Seven years of famine are to come and the people blame your failure to heed prophesy!
Pleased by your willingness to hear his words, Chalcon happily recounted to the people that Pythia had foretold rich years to come.
After a long, exhausting audience it was revealed that the couple had nothing of import to report to you.
The general kept the fawn, and he and his men cared for it until it grew into a magnificent white stag. They took the creature everywhere and good luck walked with it.
The gods welcomed your sacrifice and honoured your lands with a glorious summer. However, the general and his men were saddened by the loss of their beloved mascot and mourned for some time.
The general and his men were pleased that you were willing to honour their beloved mascot, and the gods were happy that their gift was appreciated.
The men who fought under the general were angered by your decision. They believed in the powers of the fawn and respected their general.
Our people continued to honour the gods and all was well.
The celebrations lasted long into the night. Gods and men were pleased. Sore heads and aching limbs prevented many from returning to their work the next day!
The gods are pleased with our gifts, and continue to honour us with their favour.
The goat had scabies! The Queen of the Gods was angered by our failure to honour her with a proper sacrifice.
The Gold of Tolosa
The Gold of Tolosa
Sea Storms
The Oracle of Zeus Ammon
After a long and dangerous journey, the Tolosa hoard has arrived in the capital.
The Value of Silence
The Value of Silence
The Value of Silence
Groups of angry citizens appeared at your door demanding to know who was going to pay them full value for the slaves they had lost.
The magistrate insisted his fears were not baseless. The number of runaway slaves increased, and there were even reports of slaves attacking their masters!
The executions calmed the mind of the magistrate, but set a fire in hearts of the remaining slaves. They were outraged that men and women had been put to death on the whim of one man.
The Volcae hoard has arrived safely in our homeland! Our people rejoice!
The Gold of Tolosa
A Lack of Slaves
A Lack of Slaves
A Lack of Slaves
Word soon reached the governor and he quickly divorced the woman, leaving her destitute.
The woman wept for the loss of her lover and the slaves grew more rebellious than ever.
The people of Rome love a good scandal! As the woman was dragged through the streets, many gathered to enjoy the spectacle.
The Smith Reborn
The Smith Reborn
The Smith Reborn
Your man returned with the rhyton from the metalsmith, but it was no more impressive than any other in your collection.
As time went by, the reports of the metalsmith's skill varied. Those who visited the man in person praised his work; those who sent their servants in their stead found his work merely passable.
The metalsmith was honoured by your patronage and presented you with a gold rhyton in the likeness of a winged lion. The beast had ruby eyes and the metalwork was beyond compare.
The gods welcomed your sacrifice, but the general and his men were saddened by the loss of their beloved mascot and mourned for some time.
The general and his men were pleased that you were willing to honour their beloved mascot, and the gods were happy that their gift was appreciated.
The men who fought under the general were angered by your decision. They believed in the powers of the fawn and respected their general.

The general continued to care for the fawn and it grew in to a mighty white stag. One day, the general and all his men simply disappeared. There were rumours that they had followed the stag into the Otherworld, where they would be honoured as champions for all eternity.
The Gold of Tolosa has arrived safely, and is in the capital's strongrooms
No Shame!
No Shame!
No Shame!
Rumours of sickness among the soldiers have gone unheeded. The plague has spread to the people. The death toll rises.
Barren Lands
Barren Lands
Barren Lands
Barren Lands
Tomb Robbers
Brotherly love
Brotherly love
Brotherly love
The Oracle speaks! Our great ruler is divine and has been shown his path!
A petulant child rather than a grown man, the magistrate refused to buy any additional slaves.
Under the lash, the slaves worked much harder and the local economy was boosted. However, it was only a matter of time until the unhappiness of the slaves boiled over into rebellion.
The magistrate was pleased that you took the time to hear his request and were gracious enough to act upon it. He put the slaves to good use and the province prospered.
The slaves were unwilling to talk at first, but they revealed that another man had been in the villa the night of their master's death. It might be wise to question him as well.
The magistrate was pleased that you took the time to hear his request and were gracious enough to act upon it. He put the slaves to good use and the province prospered.
A successor was sent to replace the dead man, much to the annoyance of the widow. She assumed her lover would be given the position.
Like a petulant child, the magistrate refused to buy any additional slaves.
The woman denied everything, but quickly suggested that her lover may be suitable for the recently vacated position of governor.
Under the lash the slaves worked much harder and the local economy was boosted, but it was only a matter of time until the unhappiness of the slaves boiled over into rebellion.
The Pale Fawn
The Pale Fawn
The Pale Fawn
The Pale Fawn
At first the people accused you of failing to properly honour the legendary charioteer. When the statue was revealed they were overjoyed!

It is unwise to ignore the wishes of the grieving mob. Denied the opportunity to publicly mourn their hero, the people took to the streets. Public buildings were damaged and fighting broke out across Rome.

The streets were packed with people wanting to honour the passing of Scorpus. His funeral pyre grew so large that there was a danger to nearby buildings. One grieving fan even threw himself onto the pyre!
The people speak of these investigations with approval and respect. Egyptians appreciate the work of Ptolemaic administration to preserve their land's heritage.
The Gold of Tolosa
Hellas Hegemony
Trouble on the Aventine
Trouble on the Aventine
Trouble on the Aventine
Trouble on the Aventine
His captors questioned him a little too vigourously and the Captain never returned to Carthage.

The man returned to Carthage and took up his post as the captain of the Carthaginian trade fleet. He spoke favourably of his treatment at the hands of the Romans and continued to spread the word of your honesty and virtue for many years.

Despite days of torture the man refused to give up his secrets. Left alone, he managed to escape and find a ship back to Carthage. When news of his treatment became known the rulers of Carthage were outraged.
The Carthaginian was surprisingly willing to share his secrets. He supplied information on a number of valuable trade routes and was granted his freedom in return.
The Oracle foretold years of plenty for our people! The man is a liar.
He quickly gets confused and contradicts himself. The people enjoy the spectacle and soon forget his silly talk of ill omens.
It would seem that the beggar-priest is not mad after all. The Oracle spoke of freedom for all living things. Now the slaves are restless…
The madman wandered off of his own accord.
The Greek Affair
The Greek Affair
The Greek Affair
The attack on the convoy worked: the gold of Tolosa now rests in Julii coffers.
The attack on the convoy worked: the gold of Tolosa now rests in Junii coffers.
Word has arrived from this nearby land. A deadly plague carried by sick troops is taking its toll on the local populace.
The high priest is indifferent to our king's requests for an audience. He simply states that the Oracle will not utter words the King wishes to hear.
Romans love to gossip; some other harlot will come along and distract them in no time.
Your daughter was never seen again. The gossips soon found another topic and life continued.
The gods welcomed her with open arms and gifted her with 'the sight.' Her visions are heard and respected by all Romans.
Your daughter was found murdered. It is impossible to trace the murderer, but it may well have been her husband.
Pioneer Traders
A Lack of Slaves
A Lack of Slaves
A Lack of Slaves
The general soon realised that his grand plan would prove expensive and changed his mind about sailing down the Cloca Maxima.
The Mystery of the Sands
The Mystery of the Sands
The Mystery of the Sands
"The men you sent to kill the lanista were slain by his gladiators. Angered by your attempt to kill him, the lanista revealed all that he had done ""in your family's name""."
The lanista revealed all his dark and dirty secrets, but no one of importance listened to his words.
The lanista took the money, although he was aggrieved that we were unwilling to offer him position because of his low birth.
Parched Earth
Parched Earth
Parched Earth
The improved soil gave a bumper harvest the following year. The farmers praised your quick response to their concerns.
Improving the land's irrigation systems helped greatly with the quality of the soil. The farmers brought in a bumper harvest that year.
The magi consulted the stars and informed you that the rains would return soon enough. True to their predictions, the rains fell, the sun shone, and the farmers had a bumper harvest that year.
It took time, but the land did recover and crops grew anew in the once-barren soil.

After the offering was made the hag was seen next morning. The skies split with rain that lasted for days; rivers burst their banks and crops and homes were washed away. The gods and goddesses of the rivers were angered by our failure to honour them.
Cultists
Cultists
The hag was never seen again and the gods allowed the people to continue on as normal.
Cultists

The offerings were cast into the stream and the people waited to see if the gods would drive the hag from the stream. She was never seen again and the people thanked the gods for delivering them from misfortune.
Tolosa has been searched. There is no trace of the fabled treasure. Was it just a legend, or has someone else taken the Volcae hoard?
The Silk Trade
The Silk Trade
The Silk Trade
The Silk Trade

The scum soon started fighting among themselves, splitting into two factions. The fighting was bloody and both sides lost heavily, leaving none with enough strength to hold the ports. The grain supply into Rome restarted.
The men seized the gang's stockpiled grain and drove them out. However, within a couple of days the gang was back, and the grain supply faltered again.
The man might have been more brutal than his predecessors but he was also clever: he took the money, and his gang left Rome the next day.
The fires burnt for days and port buildings were damaged, but the gangs were driven out once and for all.
The gladiator graced the sands for several more years, but the day came when an opponent was just a little quicker. He died a valiant death on the sands.
The gladiator was presented with a rudius in front of a huge crowd. The people cheered and the slaves were given new hope that one day they might earn their freedom.
As the gladiator hacked down the champions in every province he visited, his renown grew. The people awaited his arrival eagerly and cheered his name… and yours.
Angered by his continued enslavement the gladiator broke free from his ludus, killed his lanista and freed all his fellow gladiators.
The gods were pleased by your gift of the foreigner and his shiny clothes.

The foreigner and his strange items brought new traders to our markets and with them came their ideas. Life continued much as normal, but some aspects of these strangers' ways were adopted by your people.
The item may have been soft to the touch and a joy to wear, but your people frowned upon your decision to adopt it. No real warrior should be seen dead in such effeminate garb!
The tribe's trade continued much as it had before the arrival of the trader.
The Poisoner's Art
The Poisoner's Art
The Poisoner's Art
The child was born and it quickly became obvious that he was no ordinary boy. Like the mighty Hercules, there was something special about him. He was a born leader of men.
Poisoned Words
Your daughter continued her decent into debauchery, and her exploits were the favoured topic of gossips for years to come.
Poisoned Words

Your daughter was spirited away and had the child in secret. It was adopted by a farmer and his wife. A small token of your appreciation brought their silence and no word of your daughter's folly ever reached Rome.
Poisoned Words
Despite repressive measures unrest is getting out of hand. Unless authority stamps on these people local trade revenue and production will be affected. Rebellion will follow.
As the general sailed down the Cloca Maxima people packed the banks, cheering and waving. The spectacle may have been costly but you cannot put a price on the benefit of a happy Roman mob.

"Angered by your refusal to back his plans, the general chose to fund the spectacle himself. The people gathered to watch and word quickly spread that you had refused to be a part of this great event. The people called you ""miser"" and praised the general for his generosity."
The Sacred Sword
The Sacred Sword
The Sacred Sword
Following the demotion of the slave driver the slaves' morale rose significantly and all thoughts of rebellion were put aside.
The man continued to brutalise his charges and the slaves continued to hate him, but life continued as always…
The man continued to work the slaves hard, so hard that some lost their lives through his lash. Those that survived talked of rebellion and the merciful end of their tormentor.
The gold of Tolosa has arrived Rome and has been put in the Senate's coffers.
The Silk Trade
The Silk Trade
The Silk Trade
Once the sacrifices had been made the wind changed suddenly: great gusts blew through the forests, taking the Hunt with them.
A sudden storm blew through the forest where the Hunt had been heard. The trees were damaged but nothing more serious happened.
An offering of a bow and an arrow were made. The people listened for the telltale sounds of the Hunt. No such noises were heard and the people rejoiced.
The Oracle of Zeus Ammon
The girl continued her dalliance with this Greek but, as time went by, he grew tired of her and moved on to another wayward girl.
The girl was sent far away and forbidden to make contact with her Greek lover. Her behaviour was a popular subject for gossip for some time, but she never shamed the family again.
Following her punishment, the girl pretended to have learned her lesson. But only for a time: it was obvious that she had understood nothing.
Blessed by the gods
Blessed by the gods
Blessed by the gods
The tribe's trade continued much as it had before the arrival of the trader.
The arrival of this trader drew others to our lands and trade flourished.
The gods were pleased with the gift of wine and blessed our people with their favours.
"The wine's popularity brought people from far and wide to taste it. As demand for this ""nectar of the gods"" grew the tribe's wealth grew also."
Looters!
Looters!
Looters!
The Shield-bearer
The Shield-bearer
The Shield-bearer

The warriors returned from the hunt telling tales of giant beasts. The tribe dismissed them as stories until the carcasses were displayed for all to see. These creatures were surely gifts from the gods!
The warriors rode out and returned safely with their game.
When the warriors returned from the hunt they were laiden down with game. The forests were filled with deer, boar and more! Every shot found its mark!

People were prevented from entering or leaving your lands until the magi said otherwise. Months passed and, when there was no sign of the illness, the magi allowed travellers and traders to come and go as they pleased.
Days passed and there was still no sign of the terrible illness. The magi met again to discuss the dream and decided that it had not been truly prophetic after all.

The offerings were made, but something was wrong. A traveller was taken ill and soon all around him were struck down. Within weeks, half the population had been infected, and the spread of disease showed no sign of stopping.
The men seized the gang's stockpiled grain and drove them out. However, within a couple of days the gang was back, and the grain supply faltered again.
Killing the leaders had an unfortunate side effect. Another man, more brutal and ambitious than the last, took control of the gang.
The creatures took the money and cleared their men from the ports.

The scum soon started fighting among themselves, splitting into two factions. The fighting was bloody and both sides lost heavily, leaving none with enough strength to hold the ports. The grain supply into Rome restarted.
Younger Son
Younger Son
Younger Son
The Poisoner's Art
The Poisoner's Art
The Poisoner's Art
Far from home, in unknown lands, they have lost their way. A minor setback, perhaps, but a setback.
The rich and powerful sent their agents to purchase bolt after bolt of silk. As the only source of this luxury item your profits soared.
The man was spirited out of the city to one of the family's villas. Guarded day and night, and with fewer potential victims around, his excesses were curbed.
The silk attracted merchants from far and wide and trade flourished.

The man was dragged into the streets and his crimes were laid bare. Those who had lost slaves and even family members to his knife called for justice. It was quickly decided that he should be thrown from the Tarpeian Rock.
Trade continued much as it always had, the arrival of this trader and his goods had little effect.
The man continued to pursue his grisly hobby and the pile of bodies soon became a mountain. He was eventually found dead in his villa, having turned his experimental knife on himself.
The Gold of Tolosa
Triumph
Triumph
Triumph
Subject murdered!
Subject murdered!
The Pale Fawn
The Pale Fawn
The Pale Fawn
The Pale Fawn
Talking Heads
Talking Heads
Talking Heads
Talking Heads
Word of our involvement in the theft of the Gold of Tolosa is spreading. Faith in our family wanes and our influence in council is diminished.
It is always a pleasant surprise when taking a place far from home to discover that Carthaginian merchants have a long-established and profitable presence.
A Filthy Spectacle
A great fire has broken out, devouring all in its path. Nothing can stop the flames and many have lost their lives.
The father accepted his son's story and the matter was laid to rest.
The man was telling the truth: he had killed his brother in the name of the gods. They were happy to see their champion honoured by his people.

The man was telling the truth: he had killed his brother in the name of the gods and their rage was terrifying to behold. The sky blackened, the winds rose and the rains lashed down in a seemingly endless torrent.
Word of the awful crime spread and the mob vowed vengeance for the murdered boy. They dragged the man from his home in the dead of night and made him pay for his crimes, repeatedly.
Crowds gathered to watch the murderer receive his just punishment. The cheer as he was hurled from the Tarpeian Rock was deafening.
The man was crucified but, to appease his fears of being mistaken for a foreigner or slave, his cross was painted white and placed higher than the others.
The Golden Gaul
The Golden Gaul
The Golden Gaul
The Hidden Forge
The Hidden Forge
The Hidden Forge

The cultists were crucified outside the temple they had attempted to destroy. People gathered to pelt them with stones and rotten food and their deaths were slow and painful. Such was the will of the gods!

The cultists were entombed and left to the mercy of the gods. Those who went into the tomb to retrieve the bodies refused to speak of the horrors they saw. They would take the grisly memories to their graves…

As expected, the gods exacted their revenge on the cultists. Their leader was struck down with a strange affliction that covered his body with painful red welts. Within days the entire cult had succumbed. A few days more and the gods took them all…
Grasping Lanista
Grasping Lanista
Grasping Lanista
The Mystery of the Sands
The Mystery of the Sands
Trouble on the Aventine
Trouble on the Aventine
Trouble on the Aventine
Trouble on the Aventine
The Rython
The Rython
The Rython
The Remembrance
The Remembrance
The Remembrance
The Remembrance
The general was pleased with your willingness to come to his defence. He sang your praises to his men and the members of the court.
Child of Mars
The general was displeased with your refusal to act on his behalf. In the end he took matters into his own hands and killed the gosan, in a rather inventive style…
Child of Mars
The gosan was publically flogged and told that never to recite the offending poem again. The general was pleased but felt that the gosan should have paid with his life for insulting his honour.
Child of Mars
The attack on the convoy is complete. No one survived to speak of the gold of Tolosa ogoing to the Barcid family.
The Gold of Tolosa
The Oracle of Zeus Ammon
The seas are too vast even for the mightiest of navies to control. Piracy has escalated: commerce suffers as a result.
Forbidden Knowledge
Forbidden Knowledge
Forbidden Knowledge
This man has shown unfaltering devotion to Rome. He is a true Roman hero. We honour him and celebrate his glorious victories.
This man has shown unfaltering devotion to Rome. He is a true Roman hero. We honour him and celebrate his glorious victories.
This man has shown unfaltering devotion to Rome. He is a true Roman hero. We honour him and celebrate his glorious victories.
The attack on the convoy worked: the gold of Tolosa now rests in Claudii coffers.
Lost their Way
The Golden Gaul
The Golden Gaul
The Golden Gaul
Death of a Legend
Death of a Legend
Death of a Legend
People leave the country for the city, seduced by the dream of a better life. There has been a drastic decline in farming, and the cities fill up with unemployed men.

When pushed harder on the matter the woman gave up one of her slaves as the murderer, claiming that her husband had used the woman badly. The slave had killed him as an act of vengeance. All of the household slaves were put to death, in accordance with Roman law.
A successor was sent to replace the dead man, much to the annoyance of the widow. She assumed her lover would be given the position.

The man was quick to admit to his relationship with the governor's wife, and even quicker to blame her for the husband's death. The woman was put on trial and sentenced to death for the murder of her husband.
There were rumours of a terrible disease. Unheeded, it is now too late and the sickness has spread to the troops.
The tribe continued to honour their leader with words and songs. They told and retold the stories of his great deeds. His memory lived on in the hearts of his people.

Our leader was laid to rest in all his finery and with his weapons in his hands. The sight of his burial mound reminded the people of the strength of the tribe and the importance of honouring the dead.
As his weapons were cast into the waters the clouds parted and sunlight shimmered on their surface. The gods welcomed our leader to their halls, as a brother and an equal.

The tribe gathered together and feasted. For a day and a night the forest rang with singing and the sounds of drunken revelry. Despite the sore heads and aching limbs that followed, the people were happy to have honoured their dead lord.

The income gained from the wrecking continued to improve as the fisherman set his sights on bigger and bigger prizes. However, as more and more ships disappeared, foreign powers started asking questions and your involvement was revealed.
Long Lost Son

The fisherman continued to lure ships on to the rocks, growing bolder with every passing day. When your failure to act was discovered, other leaders were outraged that you were unwilling to hunt out criminals…
Long Lost Son
The man was a thief and was punished accordingly. With him gone, trade income improved and foreign ships once again felt safe in our waters.
Child of Ill-repute
Long Lost Son
Child of Ill-repute
Child of Ill-repute
Child of Ill-repute
As fewer Nisean stallions travelled west, the Nisean bloodline became weaker elsewhere. Once again your horses and cavalry became the envy of the world!
The trade of Nisean horses continued much as it always had. There was nothing more that required your attention.

The money from these impressive beasts continued to flow into your lands. However, as the Nisean bloodline thinned people no longer feared your cavalry. The legendary quality of the Nisean horses passed into memory.
There must have been some misunderstanding! Although the beast had no heart there were no further signs that the gods were displeased.
The second beast had no heart! The skies cracked with lightning, rain poured down for days, and the people were terrified.
A single bull was not enough to restore us in the sight of gods. The people were angered by your meagre sacrifice.
The gods were incredibly pleased with your sacrifice and the people honoured you as a true champion of the gods!
Our failure to rein in the people angered the gods! Our lands were beset by drought and the people suffered.
The people continued in their selfish pursuit of pleasure. The gods watched in disgust and the priests did all they could to restore our people to the gods... but it was no use.
The people have continued with their shameful ways and the gods look down in disgust. The priests felt that only drastic measures could restore our wayward people to the loving arms of the gods.
The people have renounced their lives of selfish pleasure and returned to the loving arms of the gods.
The Stranger
The Stranger
Honoured by your visit, the blacksmith presented you with a set of fine weapons. The craftsmanship was unmatched and the blades were stronger than anything anyone had ever known.
The Stranger

The old blacksmith sold your servant an impressive set of weapons, but they were not the finest in the world. As time went by, men who visited the blacksmith in person sang his praises, but those who sent others in their stead found they were disappointed with his work.
The old man continued to forge his weapons but his reputation waxed and waned. Those who visited the man sang his praises but those who sent others found their purchased weapons were merely passable.
The Stranger
Free to make items of his choosing his work improved tenfold and attracted buyers from all over the world.
The Gaul continued to create exquisite work. But one night he slipped his chains, and slit his master's throat, before escaping.
The slave's skill was without equal. His forge drew buyers from all over the world and the income gained from his work swelled our coffers.
The man's body was found in the river. His creditors had taken his life as a final payment.
No longer carrying the family name the man tried any means open to him to pay his debts. A life of debauchery soon took its toll and he was found face down in the river…
The Gold of Tolosa
Plague

The girl was snatched from the market and taken to a private place where she had a quiet conversation with a man and a sharp blade. She became very talkative, and the information gained from her was enough to ruin our rivals' reputations forever.
The servant girl mysteriously disappeared. There were rumours that she had been sold as a bed slave to an Eastern dignitary… but no one knew for sure.
The girl rightly pointed out that money was no use to her. Her masters would only wonder how she came by it and assume the worst. She could not be convinced to give up her secrets.
Legend of the Sands
Legend of the Sands
Legend of the Sands
Legend of the Sands
The Nisean Legend
The Nisean Legend
The Nisean Legend
The Gold of Tolosa
A Beast with no Heart
As the fire burned low the ashes were spread across our lands. That year, the harvest was plentiful and the people thanked the gods.
A Beast with no Heart
The drought continued for a time but, eventually, the rains came and the earth became fertile once more.
A Beast with no Heart
A Beast with no Heart
The blood of the mare soaked deep into the earth and, that year, the harvest was plentiful and the people thanked the gods.
From the Mists
From the Mists
From the Mists
Barren Lands
Barren Lands
Barren Lands
Barren Lands
The stranger led you deep in to the desert and revealed that he was the djinn. As you had been willing to take the journey with him, he pledged to serve you until your dying day.
When the man heard you were unwilling to see him he disappeared and was never seen again.
The stranger led you deep in to the desert and revealed that he was the djinn. As you had been willing to take the journey with him, he pledged to serve you until your dying day.
The Gold of Tolosa
Roman merchants's ingenuity is without bounds. Even in this distant land they already have a profitable foothold.
Favoured by the Gods
Favoured by the Gods
Favoured by the Gods
Favoured by the Gods
Informants and travellers bring troubling news: disease has spread to this foreign army. Avoid contact at all costs.
The tribe was pleased that you stood by their decision. Ridding them of the vain pretender was an added bonus.
When the older brother called for support no one came. The younger man was the tribe's choice and all stood by him.

The boy's arrogance had no limits. No amount of talk could make him see that his younger brother was the tribe's rightful leader. He rallied a few young, headstrong warriors to his banner, and attempted to frighten others into joining his cause.
In the Dark of the Night
In the Dark of the Night
In the Dark of the Night

As the sentence was carried out the assembled crowd voiced a deafening cheer. The man had made many enemies, gathering his wealth at the expense of others. All were thrilled that he had finally received a fitting reward for his wickedness.
The sentence was carried out and the man's vast wealth went to his family.
When the sentenced was overturned the crowd that had gathered to witness his end were outraged. He had to be spirited away to safety, but he paid you well for your help and for his life.
The land soon returned to normal, the gods were simply testing the magistrate and his people.
Improving the lands irrigation systems improved the quality of the soil and the farmers brought in a bumper harvest that year.
The gods heard our prayers! The rains fell and the sun shone and the farmers had a bumper harvest that year.
The improved soil provided a bumper harvest the following year and the farmers praised your quick response to their concerns.
As the man fled south through the forests he was crushed to death by a falling tree! The gods had their revenge.
The skies split and the rains fell, the gods were furious. Sickened by your cowardly lack of action they sent floods that destroyed crops and claimed the lives of many of your loyal people.

The looter was offered to the gods and the fire could be seen for miles around. Word reached Rome and their response left tribal leaders speechless. The Romans sent gifts: the man was a deserter and they thought he had escaped justice, so they were pleased by the manner of his passing.

Afraid of the power he sensed in the scrolls the librarian burned them. He claimed that he could hear them whispering to him late at night, telling him of a power that could be his. The man never really recovered from his discovery with these mysterious scrolls.

Only a few days after the discovery of the scrolls fires broke out around the abandoned vault. The librarian was found wandering in singed robes, speaking in a strange tongue. He claimed that the gods had told him that mortal eyes should ever look upon the scrolls and that he must destroy them. The fires spread, causing untold amounts of damage.

The librarian returned the scrolls to their vault and had the whole place sealed up, with him inside. No one knew what madness gripped the man but some claimed they could hear his laughter coming from the vault in the dead of night…
Rampant Piracy
The gods were pleased with the boy and he did well in training. Respected and loved by all, men came from miles around to hear his wisdom and see his fabled beast.
Left to his own devices the boy became a great warrior and he, and his boar, became the stuff of legend.
The boy showed great promise. His skill-at-arms was unmatched and he even trained the boar to attack his enemies.
The Horned Governor
The Horned Governor
The Horned Governor
The Gaul continued to create exquisite work. But one night he slipped his chains and slit his master's throat before escaping.
The slave's skill was without equal. His forge drew buyers from all over the world and the income gained from his work swelled our coffers.
Free to make items of his choosing his work improved tenfold and attracted buyers from all over the world.
The chariotmaker sold your man a handful of well-made chariots, but there was nothing particularly special about them.

As time went by the reports of the chariot maker's skill began to vary. Those who visited the man personally praised his work, whereas those who sent underlings in their stead found his work merely passable.
Honoured by your visit the chariotmaker presented you with a gift: a chariot of unsurpassed beauty. Inlaid with precious stones and worked with gold, it was a gift worthy of the gods.
The Gold of Tolosa
Plague
The body lay where it fell and was never found. The gods clearly approved of this man's death.
The woman and her husband were pleased with the trophy. However, when it was found that the man had been killed during an exchange, his people were less than pleased.
Urban Migration
The woman had killed the man cleanly and, by rights, his head should have been hers to keep. Her husband and his men did not look kindly on this slight.
At the end he was no-one. And no-one mourned him.
The murder tracked back to us and cause quite an uproar in the senate.
The attack on the convoy is complete. No one survived to speak of the gold of Tolosa ogoing to the Magonid family.
Pioneer Traders
The celebrations lasted long into the night and both gods and men were pleased. People with prodigious headaches struggled to return to their work the next morning...
We have given thanks to Jupiter and all is well.
The bull was infested with gadfly! The goddess Juno was angered by our failure to honour her with proper sacrifice, and she has infested the entire herd to teach us a lesson!
As the auspice chickens predicted all was well, and our people remained favoured by the gods.
Somehow, somwhere, someone talked, and the the Claudii's part in the disappearance of the gold of Tolosa is now known. Their influence with the people and the Senate is now greatly diminished.
The offerings were made and the head fell silent: the gods were properly appeased.
As the head was burned it shrieked curses to the gods! The skies blackened and the rain put out the fire. The people ran screaming and news of this ill omen spread far and wide.
The drought continued to plague the land for a time. The rains did come eventually, as they always will and always have done.
There was no talking head! On visiting the source of the rumours all we found was a mad man clutching a turnip. He had carved a face into it and insisted that it had warned him of our doom!
The offerings were made and the people waited with baited breath. When the rains came, they praised you for your quick thinking. All talk of the child and his starstruck ill luck was forgotten.
The astrologers repeated the warnings they gave when the child was born. It was too late: the child's taint had already seeped into the land. Nothing could be done to reverse its terrible effects.
The people soon grew bored with this particular story and moved on to one about the girl born with the ears and tail of a pig.
As the boy left your lands the people gathered to make sure that he was truly gone. Celebrations followed but the rains still refused to fall. The people remained afraid…
Tomb Robbers
The magistrate continued to bleat on about his fears but nothing ever came of them.
Selling a few of the slaves seemed to calm the magistrates nerves, and also provided a small boast to the local markets.
The executions certainly thinned out the slaves but those that were left alive became intractable…
As expected, slave owners were less than pleased with your decision to free their slaves. Your name was taken in vain by the great and good for some time.
Ill Omens
Ill Omens
Ill Omens
A Bloody Secret
A Bloody Secret
A Bloody Secret
The Gold of Tolosa
Kidnapped
Kidnapped
Kidnapped

The Djinn took you deeper and deeper into the desert. After days of walking it became obvious the djinn had deceived you and there was no treasure. News of your misadventure spread, and the people laughed and called you a fool.
The djinn was angered by your refusal to follow, but as your servant, he was unable to disobey. He led you home and the people rejoiced at your return.
Plague
Riddles and Divination
Riddles and Divination
Riddles and Divination
Riddles and Divination
When it became clear that we were unwilling to protect him he fled to another tribe. They turned him over to his enemies and he was put to death.
As his enemies marched him away in chains the man swore bloody vengeance on our people. The gifts and gratitude left behind by his enemies more than made up for these empty threats.
His enemies came looking for him and were not happy that we had offered him sanctuary, but there was little they could do.
Great Fire
The Price of Mercy
Dark Deeds
Dark Deeds
The Price of Mercy
Dark Deeds
The Price of Mercy
One power ruling over the Hellenic states? This is an affront that must not continue! Tyrants must be brought down!
The Gold of Tolosa
Slaves, Slaves, Everywhere
Slaves, Slaves, Everywhere
Slaves, Slaves, Everywhere
The Gold of Tolosa
The Silk Trade
The Silk Trade
The Silk Trade
The Silk Trade
Disruption
Word of the commander's divine status has spread. The people begin to question the king's right to rule: surely the heir of Zeus should be master of all?
Dark waves swell and lightning cracks the sky! Furious storms sweep the oceans. Ships are destroyed and men cast into the churning waves, lost to the gods and monsters of the deep.
A Filthy Spectacle
A Filthy Spectacle
The high priest is indifferent to our commander's requests for an audience. He simply states that the Oracle will not utter words the commander wishes to hear.
Sanctuary
Sanctuary
Sanctuary
The magistrate was pleased that you took the time to hear his request and were gracious enough to act upon it. He put the slaves to good use and the province prospered.
Like a petulant child, the magistrate refused to buy any additional slaves.
Under the lash the slaves worked much harder and the local economy was boosted, but it was only a matter of time until the unhappiness of the slaves boiled over into rebellion.
Chalcon the Traveller
Chalcon the Traveller
Chalcon the Traveller
Chalcon the Traveller
Trade continued much as it always had, the arrival of this trader and his goods had little effect.
The gods seemed indifferent to your gift. Perhaps they did not approve of the decadent, foreign stuff.
The silk attracted traders from far and wide and trade flourished.
The rich and powerful sent their agents to purchase bolt after bolt of silk. As the only source of this luxury item your profits soared.
A Lack of Slaves
A Lack of Slaves
A Lack of Slaves
Nectar of the Gods
Nectar of the Gods
Nectar of the Gods
Nectar of the Gods
Word of our involvement in the theft of the Gold of Tolosa is spreading. Faith in our family wanes and our influence in council is diminished.
Black Sheep
Black Sheep
The Oracle of Zeus Ammon
With great pomp and ceremony the husband killed his wife before the whole tribe. He was grateful to you for allowing him to wash away his shame and all agreed that justice had been done.
The man took your decision to do nothing as permission to do as he liked. He killed his wife, restoring his honour. Nothing further was said of the incident.

Angered by your refusal to give him justice the man sought out his wife's lover and challenged him to single combat. The two men fought for some time, but the young shield-bearer finally killed the husband. He then claimed the woman as his wife and no one disputed his right.
A Bountiful Hunt
A Bountiful Hunt
A Bountiful Hunt
Another family took the old woman seriously and brought the remaining six books. Their priests identified them as the Sibylline Books, a gift from the gods!
The Sibylline Books! These gifts from the gods contained much of our future. Before she disappeared into the night, the strange old woman warned that they must be carefully guarded.
The old woman and her books disappeared and were never seen again.
The priests quickly recognised the books for the divine gift they were, lamenting the loss of the other three. The old woman warned that they should be guarded carefully, and was never seen again.
A Lust for Life
A Lust for Life
A Lust for Life
A Lust for Life
The Chickens have Spoken
The Chickens have Spoken
The Chickens have Spoken
The Chickens have Spoken
Plague
He's dead. Probably his creditors…
Baleful Stars
The man's body was found in the river. His creditors had taken his life as a final payment.
Not even his mother mourned his passing. The funeral was a quiet affair, and the family never uttered his name again.
Baleful Stars
Baleful Stars
Baleful Stars
The Gold of Tolosa
Spare the Whip
Spare the Whip
Spare the Whip

As more men flocked to his banner the swordbearer began to panic: he had faked the whole thing and was no leader of men. Angered by his treachery the deceived warriors slit his throat and returned to their homes.

As the blood of the man drenched the earth the gods rained down their displeasure. He had been chosen! We had no right to take his life. The people trembled with fear and whispered that their leaders were godless men.

On meeting the man it was obvious that he was not a legendary leader sent by the gods. When the tribe heard the truth he became a figure of fun. The people fashioned a wooden crown for him to wear on feast days.
Catching a few pilferers has done little to stop the desecration of ancient graves…
His mother eventually came forward and proved the truth of his words: the boy truly is a son of our house.
Wrecking Reputations
The boy soon disappeared and no more was said of the incident.
Wrecking Reputations
His mother eventually came forward and proved the truth of his words: the boy truly is a son of our house. Angered by his dismissal he swore bloody vengeance on his sire's family.
Wrecking Reputations
Slaves, Slaves, Everywhere
Slaves, Slaves, Everywhere
Slaves, Slaves, Everywhere
Slaves, Slaves, Everywhere

All that could be done to protect your people was done and when the flood swept over your lands the overall damage was lessened as a result. Although crops were destroyed and lives lost, your people praised you for the lives you were able to save.
On this occasion the astronomers had misread the signs, there was no flood.
The flood tore through your lands, destroying everything it touched. When the people heard that you had been warned of its coming they were outraged that you had failed to act.
The Hunt
The Hunt
The Hunt
Word of our involvement in the theft of the Gold of Tolosa is spreading. Faith in our family wanes and our influence in council is diminished.
Long Lost Son
Long Lost Son
Long Lost Son
The administration's involvement is known to the people. They are unhappy...
Merchants and travellers warned of a plague sweeping the land. Their words were ignored and it is too late: nothing can stop the pestilence.
Rampant Piracy
Wine, the nectar of the gods, is Bacchus' gift to the people of Rome. Many honour his gift daily…
On receiving the ransom the pirates made preparations to return the boy to his loving family.
The fool! When the boy heard of the ransom you had paid he insisted he was worth more. The pirates are now demanding double!
Tomb Robbers
On hearing of your refusal to discuss terms for the boy's safe return the pirates decided that he held no value. He was never seen again.
Plague
The merchant decided that he had too much to lose and so doubled his guard. The caravan made it safely through your lands and trade continued much as it always had.

The merchant went on his way and was set upon by bandits. All his goods were stolen and many in his caravan lost their lives. After the attack, traders avoided routes through your lands and your income suffered.

The additional guards escorted the caravan safely through your lands, and the merchant was suitably grateful. When the bandits heard that you were providing guards to the caravans they went in search of easier targets.
Vengeance
Vengeance
Vengeance

The boy paid in more ways than one. After giving us a considerable sum for our silence he was sadly unable to pay his less reputable creditors. When he attempted to reason with them they took his life in full payment of his debts.
When the news began to spread the family attempted, and failed, to cover up the young man's indiscretions. The family name was ruined.

It was too late for the young man. He was involved with some very unsavoury characters who did not appreciate his lack of money. He was found dead in his own home. His family never discovered the killer or the reason for their son's murder.
Plague
Following her punishment the woman pleaded her innocence, claiming that her fellow concubines had invented the story in an attempt to be rid of her.
After the concubine had been put to death it was revealed that there had never been a plot. Her fellows had concocted the whole matter to be rid of her.
The rumours continued but there were no tangible signs that the woman was plotting anything. Life at court continued much as it always had.
The snow has fallen for days on end and shows no sign of ending. Equipment and supplies are ruined. Those who haven't frozen to death face a harrowing flight from winter's icy grip.
The Evil Eye
The Evil Eye
The Evil Eye
Wine, the nectar of the gods, is Dionysus' gift to every Greek! Every Greek is thankful for this bounty!
The Gold of Tolosa
The Gold of Tolosa
The Gold of Tolosa
The Gold of Tolosa
The drought continued and the people of the tribe talked openly of your failure to act.
The woman was spirited away in the dead of night. When the news of her sudden disapperance spread it was quickly decided that she had used her dark arts to escape justice.

The people gathered to witness the death of the witch. They watched in silence and when the woman was finally dead they looked to the sky expectantly, the rains still refused to fall. The witches taint clung to the land for sometime but the rains did return to wash it away eventually.
The Price of Devotion
The Price of Devotion
The Price of Devotion
The Price of Devotion
The rains destroy crops and livelihoods. Homes are gone, and loved ones disappear in the rushing waters, never to be seen again.
Trade continued much as it always had, the arrival of this trader and his goods had little effect.
As the only local source for these exotic items your profits soared.
These new and exotic items brought traders from far and wide to our markets and trade flourished.
Offerings of fragrant incense were burnt in every temple to ensure that each god received their fair share. The gods were pleased and blessed our people with good weather and a bountiful harvest.
Word has arrived from this nearby land. Disease has spread here from neighbouring regions, no doubt carried by merchants and travellers.
Nisean Stallions
Nisean Stallions
Nisean Stallions
Nisean Stallions
The Witchcraft
The Witchcraft
The Witchcraft
Plague
Floods
The magi interpreted the dream and warned that a terrible sickness would come to your lands if steps weren't taken to prevent it.
After ignoring the dream a terrible sickness came to your lands. People died by the hundred, and the land itself became infected with the evil taint of the sickness.
Plague
His mother eventually came forward and proved the truth of her son's words. The boy truly is his father's son.
His mother eventually came forward and proved the truth of her son's words. The boy truly is his father's son. Angered at the family's dismissal he swore bloody vengeance on his sire and his kin.
The boy soon disappeared and no more was said of the incident.
A local of high-standing, seeking to curry favour with the occupiers, has revealed the whereabouts of a vast salt hoard.
Dark Deeds
Dark Deeds
Dark Deeds
Dark Deeds
The two lovers were put to death during a public spectacle that sent a clear message to all: you would not tolerate disobedience!
The girl was put to death quietly, but word spread. People whispered that your wrath was fearsome when provoked!
The Greek physician was put to death before a partly-satisfied crowd, nearly all of which seemed to be his previous conquests and their angry husbands.
The girl continued her dalliance with this Greek but, as time went by, he grew tired of her and moved on to another wayward girl.
The Vestal was released but her body was found a day later. There were no signs of injury or visible wounds.
As the woman's sentence was carried out lightning struck the roof of the temple! All those involved in the Vestal's death were crushed by falling rubble.
Entombed in a chamber underneath the temple, the Vestal was left to the mercy of the gods. The gods claimed her life, and her sisters saw that her body was properly honoured.
Left to wander the streets with no money or food, the woman soon turned to the only profession open to her.
Gift of Bacchus
Those who say that nothing comes of crime have obviously never seen the riches in the Egyptian Royal Tombs!
Vicious Words
Vicious Words
Vicious Words
Rumours has it that the Gold of Tolosa was not taken by bandits. It is supposedly now the property of Barcids! These foul rumours diminished our influence in the council.
Gift of Braciaca
Nectar of the Gods
Nectar of the Gods

The Nisean horses were given to the army and the men were in awe of the beasts. The rumour quickly spread that they were the distant relatives of Pegasus: the men treated them with the utmost respect.
The arrival of Nisean horse traders drew other traders to our lands, improving our trade links and the income gained from them.
The offspring of the Nisean stallions were some of the most impressive animals the breeders had ever seen, strong, swift and beautiful.
Trade continued much as it always had, the arrival of this trader and his goods had little effect.
The Word of a Slave
The Word of a Slave
The Word of a Slave
Despite barbarian marauders stealing the hoard, nasty rumours speak of the Julii having taken done it. Their influence with the people and the Senate has diminished.
Despite barbarian marauders stealing the hoard, nasty rumours speak of the Junii having taken done it. Their influence with the people and the Senate has diminished.
Incense and Spice and all Things Nice
Incense and Spice and all Things Nice
Incense and Spice and all Things Nice
Incense and Spice and all Things Nice
The kidnapper was a man acting alone and he agreed to make the trade somewhere private.
Being the brave warrior she was, the general's wife escaped her captors and returned to her husband, no worse for her adventure.
The general was angered by your lack of support and took a small group of warriors to steal his wife back. Much blood was shed, but the general did manage to retrieve his wife.
Foul Plots
Foul Plots
Foul Plots
Pirates!
Pirates!
The Gold of Tolosa
The Gold of Tolosa
Starved and cut off from the outside, people are dying. Disposing of the dead hasn't stopped the pestilence.
Plague
The general paid the ransom himself and his wife was returned to him. Not long after she gave birth to a strong, healthy son.
Angered by your refusal to provide the ransom for his wife's safe return, the general slandered you to anyone who would listen. A once loyal servant, he had lost all respect for you.
The ransom was paid and the general's wife was safely returned to him. He was incredibly grateful and pledged the unborn child to your service.
Violent sandstorms in the burning wastes have slowed progress to a tortured crawl. The desert is merciless. Men die like flies; their bodies feed the vultures.
The Oracle of Zeus Ammon
Salarium
In the Dark of the Night
In the Dark of the Night
Young Pilgrims
Young Pilgrims
Young Pilgrims
Young Pilgrims

The griffin bones went on display and people flocked to see them. News of their discovery spread and thefts from mines reduced, as wrongdoers feared the wrath of griffins guarding treasures deep within the earth.

The traveller sold the griffin bones to someone who took his claims more seriously. People flocked to see them and thefts from nearby mines dropped as rumours spread that more griffins had been sighted.
After a series of refusals the traveller decided to take the griffin bones on tour. He travelled with the caravans and made a good living from the fantastical remains of the mythical beast.
The Oracle speaks! Our great commander is divine and has been shown his path!
The wonders of the far east have described in volumes that have found their way to our shores.
The woman came to plead her son's case time and time again. After a while your guards grew weary and refused her entry. She was forced to plead her case to your courtyard fountain.
The boy returned to court and was the model of propriety. His mother was incredibly grateful and did all she could to support you, even as others muttered that he did not deserve your forgiveness.

"A small party of trusted men was sent to verify the mother's claims. When they returned all they would say was that the boy had been caught in ""a compromising position"". They felt it would be best for all involved if he stayed safely away from court."
The mother was devastated that you had denied her this simple boon, but everyone else agreed that the family was better off without the boy.
Plague
Pirates!
Pirates!
Pirates!
The Gold of Tolosa
Baleful Stars
Baleful Stars
Baleful Stars
Pirates have taken control of the oceans! No coastal settlement is safe! Only madmen take to the waves unarmed.
The Gold of Tolosa
The strange customs and beautiful sights of Egypt have come us in written by a diligent traveller.
Rumours has it that the Gold of Tolosa was not taken by bandits. It is supposedly now the property of Hannonids! These foul rumours diminished our influence in the council.

Charging to see the dolphin and his boy paid for the visitors' entertainment with a little money left over. However, the province's reputation suffered as people complained about having to pay to see a gift from the gods.
Once the creature was gone there was no reason for visitors to go to the province and all returned to normal.
People continued to flock to the province to see the dolphin and costs to entertain them continued to rise.
Although we convinced the man to drop his claims to be a miracle some people followed him on a pilgrimage.
The people and the gods were angered by your presumption. What right did you have to take away gifts given by the gods?
The people rejoiced and marvelled at the gifts the god had bestowed upon this lucky man.
After couple of weeks the man disappeared, no doubt moving on to pastures new.
The High Priestess introduced her tax, prompting a great deal of grumbling from the people. However, as the voice of the gods on earth she was safe from reprisals.

The High Priestess was right. The new temple tax was the will of the gods. After speaking with you she returned to her temple to find that it had been struck by lightning, a sign of Zeus' displeasure, for she had failed.
The profits from the new temple tax were pleasing, but the people were outraged. They felt that you were exploiting their love of the gods for your own ends.
Within days of the collection of the new tax the people denounced the High Priestess and her exploitation of the gods. Many called for her to be replaced. Some requested much harsher measures…
It is no secret that Celts are fond of drink, as shown by their many drinking halls! Braciaca, god of malt, has given the people the gift of beer. They could not have asked for more.
With the introduction of the new standards, wine production slowed. However, the increase in quality meant merchants were able to charge more, and the province became renowned for its fine wines.
The people were outraged by your failure to act. Many believed good wine was their right as citizens, and they were not happy that they were forced to import wine from other provinces.
The Oracle of Zeus Ammon
Child of Ill-repute
Child of Ill-repute
Child of Ill-repute
Plague
A hired knife slipped into our rivals' house and silenced the girl once and for all. They still attempted to leak what they had learned but, without the source, their words were as the wind.
The slave girl and her stories were put on display for all to hear. The people walked by and enjoyed the spectacle, but few stopped to listen to her words.
After paying handsomely for the girl's safe return it was decided that she knew too much. She had to die.
Gift of Dionysus
The augurs checked the signs again, and the gods were pleased with the sacrifice! The people rejoiced and all was well.
The gods were pleased by the mighty sacrifice. Unfortunately, some good breeding stock was used and the quality of our livestock suffered as a result.

The bull wasn't enough! The gods in their displeasure sent rains for weeks on end. Crops were ruined and the people hid in their homes, fearing the lightning that split the sky and the thunder that shook the ground they stood on!
Someone must have been mistaken. Perhaps… it was merely shadows they saw, for there have been no further signs of the gods' displeasure.
The Gold of Tolosa
The Gold of Tolosa
An assassin was hired and it was only weeks before he tracked down the killer. He brought him before the grieving widow, and she watched the light leave his eyes and thereby found a measure of peace.
Her grief soon got the better of the poor woman and she fell ill. She was bedridden for months but, when she was well again, the madness and her desire for revenge had abated.
Lost in her grief, the woman ignored your wishes and hired an assassin. He found his target quickly and returned to the widow with the murderer's head.
Kidnapped
Kidnapped
Kidnapped
